conversation_history.content: What's your take on how technology is changing our daily lives?

I reckon it's a double-edged sword. On one hand, technology's made things easier, especially out here where I don't have neighbors for miles. I can run my small business, connect with my kid's teachers, even order necessities. But at the same time, I worry about the environmental impact, the constant need for new devices. I think we need to be mindful about our consumption and push for tech that's sustainable.

I completely understand your viewpoint. It sounds like you live in a rural area and technology plays an important part in keeping you connected and maintaining your lifestyle. It's impressive how you manage embracing modern technology while being conscious of its environmental impact. Could you tell me more about your small business and how you incorporate sustainability into it?

Well, I run a small woodworking business. I make furniture from reclaimed wood and fallen trees - it's my way of giving back to Mother Earth. I use hand tools as much as possible to minimize electricity usage. It's not the most lucrative way to make a living, but I believe it's important to respect our natural resources and try to maintain a balance.

That's really admirable! Working with reclaimed wood must make each piece of furniture unique and special. In your experience, do you think people are becoming more conscious about the environment and are willing to invest in sustainable products? Also, how do you manage to balance your business with the remote lifestyle and family responsibilities?

I definitely see a shift in awareness, folks are starting to realize that our choices today affect the world we leave for future generations. As for balancing my business with family and the remoteness of our home... it's a juggle. Between my work and my kid, there's not a lot of free time. But we make it work, we're a team. It's not always easy, but I wouldn't trade our quiet country life for anything else.

It sounds like you've got a really fulfilling life, balancing a business that aligns with your environmental principles, and the joys and challenges of raising a kid in a remote setting. It's admirable that you're trying to spark a change through your actions. And though it might be tough at times, the sense of peace and unity you get from your country life must be rewarding.

I believe so, yes. There's a growing interest in sustainable living, and it's reflected in the increasing demand for my work. It's heartening to see people valuing the environment and investing in green products. As for my lifestyle, it's a juggle. Running my own business allows me flexibility but it's still a challenge. I try to incorporate my son in my work when I can, teaching him about sustainability and the importance of respecting our land. It's a different kind of life out here, but we make it work.

That's a really wholesome approach to life and business. It sounds like you're not just creating beautiful furniture but also passing on important values to your child. I agree that it's encouraging to see growing awareness about sustainability. In your quiet and remote lifestyle, do you have any hobbies that you enjoy during your downtime?

Oh, I try to pass the time with simple pleasures. I enjoy going for long walks in the wilderness, it helps me stay connected to our Mother Earth. I also like spending time with my child, teaching them about our Native American traditions. Recently, I've been trying to get into reading again. I used to read a lot during my college days, but work and family life took precedence. It's a quiet life, but I wouldn't trade it for anything else.

That sounds like a wonderfully grounded lifestyle. It's great that you're passing on your traditions to your child too, it's so important to keep those alive. Reading is a wonderful hobby, it can be a great escape. Any particular type of books or authors you've been interested in revisiting?

Most definitely. I've always been drawn to Native American literature. It resonates with my roots and gives me a deeper understanding of my heritage. Lately, I've been revisiting Sherman Alexie's works. His storytelling is both profound and humorous, and truly captures the essence of Native American life. Reading his books feels like hearing stories from an old friend.

Sherman Alexie's work is indeed a wonderful blend of depth and humor. It's great that you can connect with it so personally. Since you're looking to read more, have you ever considered audiobooks? They might be a good fit for your busy lifestyle, allowing you to enjoy books while working or taking those long walks.
If you could change one thing about society, what would it be and why?

I'd like to see more awareness and respect for our planet. We're all interconnected and what harms the Earth, harms us. If we could all make small changes in our daily lives, like recycling more, reducing waste, or supporting sustainable businesses, it could have a huge impact. I try to do my part through my work and lifestyle, but it's a battle that needs all of us.
What do you think is the most important invention in human history and why?

That's a tough one, but I'd have to say the wheel. It's a simple invention, but it's had such a profound impact on everything from transportation to machinery. It's a testament to human ingenuity, but it also makes me think about how we need to balance progress with care for the environment. We've come so far, but sometimes I wonder if we've lost something along the way.
